thread.title: 'RUTHLESS' Tory plot to snatch Labour heartlands that could spell END for Corbyn
thread.title_full: 'RUTHLESS' Tory plot to snatch Labour heartlands that could spell END for Corbyn

title: 'RUTHLESS' Tory plot to snatch Labour heartlands that could spell END for Corbyn
text:
GETTY Jeremy Corbyn's leadership may be turning off voters, top Tories claim 
A Tory party board member told the Sunday Telegraph: “There was a ruthless strategy of targeting vulnerable Lib Dem seats in the last Parliament. 
“There was something in the region of 30 potentially we were going after. There was a ruthless strategy of targeting vulnerable Lib Dem seats in the last Parliament. Tory source 
“You can expect to see that strategy now almost moved across to looking at 30 or so Labour seats in the North that could be highly vulnerable.” Corbyn looks crushed following by-election defeat Fri, February 24, 2017 Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn leaves his home following a humiliating blow by the Conservatives after snatching Copeland in a by-election victory. The struggling politician was talking on the day his party lost a by-election to the government, the first time this has happened in over 30 years. Adam Gray / SWNS.com 1 of 10 Jeremy Corbyn is seen at Savoy Place in London where the Labour leader was giving a speech on Brexit 
The board member added that the strategy previously targeted Lib Dem constituencies, but “similar issues are now bubbling away in safe Labour seats”. 
Downing Street insiders claim Theresa May’s pitch to “just about managing” families means the Tories may be perfectly positioned to win over traditionally left-wing voters. GETTY A 'ruthless' strategy saw the Tories sweep up swathes of Lib Dem seats in 2015 
A source said: “The Prime Minister’s political positioning is she wants to be the centre ground candidate. She has explicitly talked about that. 
“The point about being the centre ground candidate is that you attract the people on the Left wing rather than appealing to the right and going deliberately after Ukip voters.” 
But Jeremy Corbyn’s woes may not end there, according to Ukip’s leader in Wales. 
Neil Hamilton told Express.co.uk that his Eurosceptic party will replace Labour as the dominant force in Wales because Corbyn’s cohort of politicians have lost touch with ordinary voters. Related articles
